paragraphs.text:
%md
# Understanding how Python is configured with BDC

The servers in your BDC cluster have two separate installations of Python: "system" and "user"

+ System Python: This is version 2.6.6. This is the version that is shipped and standard with the version of Oracle Linux currently used in BDC.  This version is left unchanged to not disrupt other operating system processes and procedures which depend on it.
+ User Python : This is version 2.7.x. BDC configures this version for PySpark and Zeppelin.  It is located at /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/python
    
It should be noted that the default PATH for shell sessions will pickup the system python installation, but the BDC tools (like Zeppelin and pySpark) are configured for the user python installation.

You should be using the User Python.  See below for examples on how to add packages to the User python installation.

msg.data:
Understanding how Python is configured with BDC

The servers in your BDC cluster have two separate installations of Python: “system” and “user”

  • System Python: This is version 2.6.6. This is the version that is shipped and standard with the version of Oracle Linux currently used in BDC. This version is left unchanged to not disrupt other operating system processes and procedures which depend on it.
  • User Python : This is version 2.7.x. BDC configures this version for PySpark and Zeppelin. It is located at /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/python

It should be noted that the default PATH for shell sessions will pickup the system python installation, but the BDC tools (like Zeppelin and pySpark) are configured for the user python installation.

You should be using the User Python. See below for examples on how to add packages to the User python installation.

paragraphs.title: Illustration of the 2 Python installations
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sleep 2 # use a sleep so that output does not get garbled by zeppelin issue
echo "System python versions."
python -V
pip -V

sleep 8
# use a sleep so that output does not appear out of order
echo ".."
echo ".."

echo "User python versions."
/u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/python -V
/u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/pip -V

msg.data:
System python versions.
Python 2.6.6
pip 9.0.1 from /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages (python 2.6)
..
..
User python versions.
Python 2.7.14
pip 9.0.1 from /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages (python 2.7)

paragraphs.title: Illustration that Zeppelin and Pyspark are configured for the user Python installation (2.7)
How to install additional packages for the User python installation
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# This will put packages into /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/

sudo /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/pip install numpy

msg.data:
Collecting numpy
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/ea/7d/9f99896cc3f4834871619a36da2a833c71a2178a5bdadd4fff40c261c119/numpy-1.14.3-cp27-cp27m-manylinux1_x86_64.whl (12.1MB)
Installing collected packages: numpy
Successfully installed numpy-1.14.3
You are using pip version 9.0.1, however version 10.0.1 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the 'pip install --upgrade pip' command.

paragraphs.title: Example to show that your package was installed
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
import numpy
a1 = numpy.array([1,2,3,4,5])
a1sum = a1.sum()
print(a1sum)

paragraphs.title: Example to show that your package works with spark
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#simple example from https://gist.github.com/koverholt/a2cc2a0ab51acb13ae57
import numpy as np
 
def mult(x):
    y = np.array([2])
    return x*y
 
x = np.arange(200)
distData = sc.parallelize(x)
 
results = distData.map(mult).collect()
 
print results

%md
# Connecting to Oracle Database From Python

There are two good methods to connect to Oracle Databases from Python.

+ Use Spark APIs to read/write JDBC from PySpark.  See the Extras notebooks "Working with Oracle Database" for some Spark JDBC examples
+ Use the cx_Oracle module

msg.data:
Connecting to Oracle Database From Python

There are two good methods to connect to Oracle Databases from Python.

  • Use Spark APIs to read/write JDBC from PySpark. See the Extras notebooks “Working with Oracle Database” for some Spark JDBC examples
  • Use the cx_Oracle module

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Mandatory Pre-Requisite Steps:  Run the Extras/Working with Oracle Database notebook


Be sure to complete the steps in the Extras/Working with Oracle Database notebook before continuing.

msg.data:
Mandatory Pre-Requisite Steps: Run the Extras/Working with Oracle Database notebook

Be sure to complete the steps in the Extras/Working with Oracle Database notebook before continuing.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Using PySpark APIs to read/write JDBC to OracleDB

msg.data: Using PySpark APIs to read/write JDBC to OracleDB

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# BE SURE TO UPDATE THE CONNECT STRING BELOW (the second part of the string)
url = "jdbc:oracle:thin:@//" + "hostname:1521/PDB1.yourvalues.oraclecloud.internal"

# BE SURE TO UPDATE THE USER AND PASSWORD
properties = {
    "user": "youruser",
    "password": "yourpassword"
}

jdbcDF = spark.read.jdbc(url=url, table="user_tables", properties=properties)
    
jdbcDF.printSchema()

jdbcDF2 = spark.read.jdbc(url=url, table="(select sysdate from dual)", properties=properties)
    
jdbcDF2.show()

%md
# Using the cx_Oracle module

For more information, see https://oracle.github.io/python-cx_Oracle/

There are some examples here: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/articles/dsl/python-091105.html

msg.data:
Using the cx_Oracle module

For more information, see https://oracle.github.io/python-cx_Oracle/

There are some examples here: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/articles/dsl/python-091105.html

paragraphs.title: Installing cx_Oracle
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# This will put packages into /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/

sudo /u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/pip install cx_Oracle

%md
# Configure the Zeppelin, YARN, and Spark environments to work with cx_Oracle 

Technically, we are configuring Zeppelin, YARN, and Spark to work with the Oracle Database Instant Client. 

First, connect to Ambari (see the Extra tutorial on Connecting to Ambari if you need help).  Then while in Ambari, do the following:

## Setup the YARN environment

- In Ambari, click on YARN.
- Then click on Configs
- Then click on Advanced
- Then expand Advanced yarn-env
- Then add these 2 lines to the top of the yarn-env template:

    export TNS_ADMIN=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/tns_admin
    export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

- Then click Save
- Name the changes "oracle instant client" and click Save again
- If you get a warning message, click Proceed Anyways
- NOTE: you do not need to restart now

## Setup the SPARK environment

- In Ambari, click on Spark2
- Click on Configs
- Expand Advanced spark2-defaults
- Edit the spark.driver.extraLibraryPath field and append this value:
:/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient/
- Then click Save
- Name the changes "oracle instant client" and click Save again


## Setup the Zeppelin environment

- In Ambari, click on Zeppelin Notebook
- Click on Configs
- Expand Advanced zeppelin-env
- Then add these 2 lines to the top of the zeppelin_env_content:

    export TNS_ADMIN=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/tns_admin
    export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

- Then click Save
- Name the changes "oracle instant client" and click Save again

## Restart services

- In Ambari, click on the Actions button underneath the list of services
- Choose Restart All Required
- Then click on Confirm Restart All

msg.data:
Configure the Zeppelin, YARN, and Spark environments to work with cx_Oracle

Technically, we are configuring Zeppelin, YARN, and Spark to work with the Oracle Database Instant Client.

First, connect to Ambari (see the Extra tutorial on Connecting to Ambari if you need help). Then while in Ambari, do the following:

Setup the YARN environment

  • In Ambari, click on YARN.
  • Then click on Configs
  • Then click on Advanced
  • Then expand Advanced yarn-env
  • Then add these 2 lines to the top of the yarn-env template:

    export TNS_ADMIN=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/tns_admin
    export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

  • Then click Save

  • Name the changes “oracle instant client” and click Save again
  • If you get a warning message, click Proceed Anyways
  • NOTE: you do not need to restart now

Setup the SPARK environment

  • In Ambari, click on Spark2
  • Click on Configs
  • Expand Advanced spark2-defaults
  • Edit the spark.driver.extraLibraryPath field and append this value:
    :/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient/
  • Then click Save
  • Name the changes “oracle instant client” and click Save again

Setup the Zeppelin environment

  • In Ambari, click on Zeppelin Notebook
  • Click on Configs
  • Expand Advanced zeppelin-env
  • Then add these 2 lines to the top of the zeppelin_env_content:

    export TNS_ADMIN=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/tns_admin
    export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

  • Then click Save

  • Name the changes “oracle instant client” and click Save again

Restart services

  • In Ambari, click on the Actions button underneath the list of services
  • Choose Restart All Required
  • Then click on Confirm Restart All

paragraphs.title: Testing cx_Oracle
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# BE SURE TO CHANGE THE youruser, yourpassword, and connect string below


#export TNS_ADMIN=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/tns_admin
#export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
#export PATH=/opt/oracle/dbconnector/instantclient:$PATH


cat << EOF > cx_oracle_test.py
#!/usr/bin/env python

from __future__ import print_function

import cx_Oracle

# Connect to Database
connection = cx_Oracle.connect("youruser", "yourpassword", "hostname:1521/PDB1.yourvalues.oraclecloud.internal")

cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT table_name, tablespace_name
    FROM user_tables
    WHERE rownum < :rownum_val""",
    rownum_val = 10)
for tname, tsname in cursor:
    print("Values:", tname, tsname)
EOF

ls -l cx_oracle_test.py
echo ".."

/u01/bdcsce/usr/local/bin/python cx_oracle_test.py
echo "done"

paragraphs.title: Testing cx_Oracle from Pyspark
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# BE SURE TO CHANGE THE youruser, yourpassword, and connect string below

from __future__ import print_function

import cx_Oracle

# Connect to Database
connection = cx_Oracle.connect("youruser", "yourpassword", "hostname:1521/PDB1.yourvalues.oraclecloud.internal")

cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT table_name, tablespace_name
    FROM user_tables
    WHERE rownum < :rownum_val""",
    rownum_val = 10)
for tname, tsname in cursor:
    print("Values:", tname, tsname)
